title: one russias top ex kgb
story: NewsTop ex-KGB officer says Vladimir Putin may order more UK assassinations unless Government hits backEXCLUSIVE: In an extraordinary interview, Oleg Kalugin tonight told the Mirror the president saw Britain as a “soft touch”Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPaul Martin21:37, 7 SEP 2018Updated08:00, 8 SEP 2018NewsFormer KGB officer Oleg Kalugin says Theresa May should now kick out the Russian ambassador after the novichok poisonings"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Russia’s top ex-KGB officers says Vladimir Putin could order more assassinations here unless the Government hits back. In an extraordinary interview, Oleg Kalugin tonight told the Mirror the president saw Britain as a “soft touch”. The former general said Theresa May should now kick out the Russian ambassador after the novichok poisonings. And he warned of the possibility of further Salisbury-style attacks. Speaking after Britain named the alleged assassins as Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov, Mr Kalugin said: “The Russians see Britain as a soft touch. “I would not rule out more assassinations. “Now that you’ve identified two assassins, I feel Britain should at the very least expel the Russian ambassador. That would send a proper signal.”  He added: “Putin is not afraid to attack those of his enemies who he thinks betrayed him personally. He would have no scruples about doing so again, through whatever agency.” Mr Kalugin, formerly chief of KGB counter-intelligence, is still on the run. If he returns to Russia he will spend the rest of his life in jail. And Mr Kalugin believes he would have been killed long ago if he lived in the UK. He was Putin’s boss when they both worked in the KGB in Leningrad in the 1970s. The pair now hate each other. Mr Kalugin was so senior, he was one of only three men in a meeting in which the KGB sanctioned the assassination of Bulgarian dissident Georgi Markov, via a poisoned umbrella, in London in 1978. And he told of his surprise over claims Russia used its GRU military intelligence unit to carry out the Salisbury attack. He said: “The only thing that has surprised me about the Skripal attack was that, according to the British, the attackers were from the GRU.  “In my days, the GRU was only there to pick up military secrets. Dealing with traitors was only a job for us, the KGB.” He added of the nature of the attack: “Just note how differently the Russians, and before them the Soviets, have acted in the US. Yes, they interfere in elections but they have never, to my certain knowledge, even attempted a political assassination on US soil. “Of course, Britain has less means to make Putin feel threatened. But it’s been lacking in strong counter-action.” Mr Kalugin went on: “Internally, I’m not sure Britain realises the dangers. Intelligence activities have been re-activated by Putin after something of a lull under [his predecessor] Boris Yeltsin. “So far, the British Government and security agencies have failed in their job. Sergei Skripal served them well as a double agent, so how could they leave him unprotected in Salisbury? “Skripal was a full colonel in Russia’s military intelligence. He was an obvious target for Russian revenge.”  Mr Kalugin lives with his Russian wife in a small bungalow on the east coast of the US, where he once posed as a reporter during his spy days. Speaking of a future visit to the UK, he said: “I know this could expose me to Putin’s assassins, but I don’t care. I’ve had a full life and I’m an old man. “My last trip to Britain was very unpleasant. The police picked me up as I arrived at Heathrow. They interrogated me about Markov. “But our embassy got me out the next day and I flew back to Moscow. I was not the killer of Georgi Markov.” But he said: “I was one of only three men who discussed whe&shyther the KGB should help the Bulgarians in &shyMarkov’s killing. I sat at KGB headquarters in 1978 with our chief Yuri Andropov [later Soviet Union President] and his deputy. It was his decision. “My department, counter-intelligence, never carried out killings. Our job was to get secret information.” Mr Kalugin went on: “Our science and technology directorate had the weapon designed and constructed in Japan. It was an umbrella that fired a small dart into Markov’s leg. I believe that department still exists.”  He said British security services should have learned after failing to protect defector Alexander Litvinenko, poisoned in London in 2006. Mr Kalugin said: “He met with his killers more than once without MI5 intervening or getting close protect&shy&shyion. “It didn’t take a genius to work out Litvinenko’s life was deeply in danger.” Mr Kalugin was called an American stooge by Putin. He said: “I publicly accused Putin of being a mass murderer for waging war in Chechnya. “I’ve also had the guts to attack Putin in a book. If I had been living in Britain instead of the US, I would have been dead long ago.” And he warned it was possible British intelligence services still have Russian double agents within them. Mr Kalugin said: “We had between 10 and 20 agents inside MI5 and MI6 when I was in charge of foreign counter-intelligence. Russia’s intelligence services, who took over from the KGB, still have that capability.” He added of Salisbury: “I think more will emerge in the next few weeks.” War game is a serious show of strength to UK  By Chris Hughes   DEFENCE AND SECURITY EDITOR  Russian President Vladimir Putin is staging war games involving 300,000 troops – and a social media campaign to wreck enemy morale. Led by military intelligence wing GRU and Spetsnaz special forces, the exercise will roll through Siberia for four days from September 11 to 15 and will include Chinese and Mongolian troops.

title: tuc 150th anniversary boss frances
story: NewsTUC 150th anniversary: Boss Frances O'Grady speaks about zero hour contracts, low pay and the rise of the Just About ManagingO’Grady's job – battling hard Tory Brexit, the eighth year of turbo-austerity, and the spectre of automation – is among the toughest public roles in the country but she is rarely short of inspirationShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist20:47, 7 SEP 2018Updated20:49, 7 SEP 2018NewsTUC general secretary Frances O'Grady has spoken to The Mirror about the issues confronting workers "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFrances O’Grady is listening to a group of underpaid care workers in a supermarket cafe. “I love my job,” one &shyexhausted woman is telling the TUC’s General Secretary. “But I’ve only had a &pound3 rise in 21 years. How much more do things cost now? “I do hours overtime, anyway. I can’t rush visits because these are elderly people, and I don’t get paid travel time. I do 50 visits some days. It’s slave labour, really, but we do it because we care.” O’Grady, 58, is in Manchester for a speech at the Mechanics Institute – the birthplace of the Trades Union Congress – as part of &shycelebrations ahead of its 150th Congress, which starts on Sunday. But these women are on the front line of modern-day labour – underpaid workers rinsed in the new zero-hour economy run by distant corporations. With the support of Unison, the care workers have recently won a court case over petrol money and are now fighting over 15-minute visits and travel time. The General Secretary has just come from the early morning picket line at Wigan Hospital, where NHS cleaners and porters are fighting privatisation.  Her job – battling hard Tory Brexit, the eighth year of turbo-austerity, and the spectre of automation – is among the toughest public roles in the country but she is rarely short of inspiration. “Those women on the picket line know we’ve got to stand up for each other,” O’Grady says. “That’s what trade unionism is.” The TUC was born in tough times, when working people were being crushed under the wheels of the Industrial Revolution. At the Mechanics Institute we sit in the room where a “congress of trades councils and other federations of trades societies” came together in 1868. A portrait of George Potter, a joiner and cabinet maker who became the first President of the TUC, hangs on the wall. O’Grady’s own heroes include Mary Macarthur, the 1903 General Secretary of the Women’s Trades Union League. “I love the way she was cutting edge,” O’Grady says, perhaps thinking of the TUC’s new app aimed at young people. “She was getting films into cinemas at the turn of the century, she brought the strikes to the people. There was also that little bit of civil disobedience, a bit of cheekiness. She wasn’t brow-beaten.”  O’Grady laughs. “And, Anne &shyScargill,” she says of the founder of Women Against Pit Closures and ex-wife of miners’ leader Arthur. “She’s still going for it at 80. No flashy ego and a twinkle in her eye. I remember when she occupied that mine. It’s ‘what are we going to do about it?’ Not the big I Am.” O’Grady’s day in Manchester is all “what are we going to do about it?” – not the Big I Am. She would rather not talk about herself, or the great founders of the movement. Instead, she meets the brilliant Rusholme bus drivers from Unite. They took strike action against First Manchester last winter after realising they were being paid nearly &pound5,000 a year less than colleagues at a depot just five miles away.  “We knew they weren’t just going to give it to us,” Unite’s Neil Clarke tells O’Grady. “We knew we were going to have to stand outside for it. But the support we had was amazing. We just wanted the same pay for the same conditions in the same city for the same job. And in the end, we won.” At St Peter’s Square, O’Grady meets the inspirational TGI Fridays strikers, some as young as 18. “We were suddenly told that 40% of service charge payments were now going to top up kitchen wages,” a waitress tells her. “We understand kitchen staff are underpaid, but why is their pay rise coming out of our pockets? This isn’t a struggling family business.” The 150th Congress, which O’Grady will address on Monday, takes place within hours of the 10th anniversary of the collapse of Lehman Brothers, which former staff are celebrating with a party. “I don’t have a problem with reunions,” says O’Grady, dryly. “But I feel sick nothing’s really changed. Those bankers got off scot-free.  “Yet there are one million more children in relative poverty since 2010. And for the majority of poor children, their mums and dads are in work. So the Tory idea that work is the best route out of poverty is one big fat lie. They work all the hours God sends and yet they are no better off. We have to do something about the greed at the top. It’s not about resenting someone’s success but about being made a fool of, taking people for mugs. “A lot of people heard Theresa May talking about the Just About Managings and thought maybe she would do something about it. Apparently not.” The youngest of five children in an Irish, working-class household, O’Grady grew up in family that was often just about managing. As we talk about a free uniform scheme in Manchester, she nods. “I remember we couldn’t afford the school skirt, which was box-pleated. I had to have one with pleats all around it. It was amazing how conscious I was of it.” She shakes her head. “We’ve got to get wages rising. We need a bloody big lift to the minimum wage.” O’Grady grew up the youngest daughter of James, a chrome fitter and shop steward at the British Leyland carworks in Cowley, Oxford, and Rita, a shopworker who later worked for the NHS.

title: devastated fish chip shop owner
story: NewsDevastated fish and chip shop owner dies of 'broken heart' just weeks after husband's deathSteven Collyer, from Torquay, died just six weeks after partner Jason Roe passed away following an illnessShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByColleen Smith23:07, 7 SEP 2018Updated08:16, 8 SEP 2018NewsSteven and Jason, pictured on their wedding day, died within weeks of each other "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated chip shop owner died of a broken heart just weeks after the death of his husband, according to friends. Steven Collyer died just six weeks after partner Jason Roe passed away following an illness.  Tributes have been paid to the couple, who lived in Torquay, Devon Live reports.  Steven, 52, had been with Jason for 28 years, and were well known in the Cardiff gay community, where he ran a number of venues before moving to the south coast. Flowers, online messages and flags have been raised in memory of Steven, who died on Tuesday, September 4.  The couple had become an important part of the community in Shiphay since opening the top-rated fish and chip shop. Before moving to Devon they also had a 'massive impact' on the gay community in Cardiff where Steven opened the first WOW gay venue in the 1990s. He also ran Koolers Nightclub and Club Cardiff. Steve and Jason had been together for 28 years and close friend Jade Smith said: Steven died of a broken heart six weeks after Jason. Jade, who was the keyholder for the Shiphay Chippy said: Steven will be sadly missed by each and every one he met.

title: drink driver loses dream job
story: NewsDrink-driver loses 'dream job' after crashing into parked car on night outMegan Fairfield, from Lancashire, ploughed her red Audi into the car when she was more than twice the legal drink driving limitShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJon MacphersonBradley Jolly21:30, 7 SEP 2018NewsFairfield got into her vehicle despite drinking heavily in Lancashire "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA drink driver who crashed into a parked car after a boozy night out has lost her dream job.  Megan Fairfield, 22, was more than twice the legal drink driving limit when she smashed her red Audi into the vehicle just 200 yards into her journey.  A court heard she had been celebrating her last shift as a care assistant with colleagues when she decided to drive the 500-yard trip home on August 1.  And now she cannot take her dream job caring for young children in the community as she's now lost her driving licence, Rossendale Free Press says.  Fairfield admitted drink driving and was given a fine and costs totalling &pound299 and disqualified from driving for 40 months, reduced by 40 weeks if she completes a drink driving course. Burnley Magistrates Court heard she had previously been disqualified in March 2016 for 17 months for the same offence.  Charlotte Crane, prosecuting, said: He [the owner of the parked car] went outside and was approached by Miss Fairfield who initially claimed that she needed assistance because her friends had run off. He called the police and they arrived. She then changed her story and accepted driving the Audi and made comments that she had been to a leaving do, had been done for drink driving before and apologised for her behaviour. The defendant, from Helmshore, near Blackburn, Lancs., provided a breathalyser reading of 78mg in 100ml of breath. The legal limit is 35mg. But her lawyer said she has been extremely remorseful since the smash.

story: NewsDubai Palm Islands-style oasis could be built on Kent coast in ambitious plans to be 'top UK attraction'The development in Kent will see a wonderland of islands created in a 12 hectare lake, with each offering something uniqueShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByVictoria ChessumLottie O'NeillBradley Jolly23:15, 7 SEP 2018Updated23:20, 7 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/plans-new-uk-garden-city-13206443,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA group of islands, inspired by the famous Palm Island Oasis in Dubai, could be built by the British coast. The development, aiming to become one of the country's most talked about attractions, would see a wonderland of islands created in a 12 hectare lake, with each island offering something unique.  Each space would be linked by walkways across the lake, and one will be dedicated to events and gigs, Essex Live reports.  There would also be floating hotel pods, eco islands for wildlife, an adventure playgound and a man-made beach.  The plans unveiled on Thursday are for the Ebbsfleet Garden City development in Gravesend, Kent. The planners aim to build it for people to use as an adventure playground. They would grow and pick their own fruit and vegetables and use it for sports. Dubai's Palm Islands took a decade to complete, with work starting back in 2001 and finishing with Palm Jumeirah in 2011. The eco islands would encourage wildlife to live on the site in a series of insect hotels, bee hives and bat boxes. There are thoughts of an innovation area for start-up businesses to sit, as well as an area for sports and a playground. There is also an ambition to create 30,000 jobs.

title: fortnite blamed after online games
story: NewsFortnite, pornography and gambling blamed in 200 divorce cases this yearExperts from Divorce-online say internet gaming can be as dangerous for relationships as drug addictionsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMatt StrudwickDave Burke21:13, 7 SEP 2018Updated21:20, 7 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/incoming/video/fortnite-battle-royale-gameplay-trailer-12192808,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFortnite has been blamed after online games were cited as the reason in 200 divorces this year. The shoot-'em-up game is played by millions around the world - but could prove as damaging to relationships as drug addictions. That's according to bosses at Divorce-online, who say they have noticed a dramatic spike in the number of cases where online gaming causes couples to split up. A spokesman for the company said: Addiction to drugs, alcohol and gambling are have often been cited as reasons for relationship breakdown but the dawn of the digital revolution has introduced new addictions. These now include online pornography, online gaming, and social media, so it is no surprise to us that more and more people are having relationship problems because of our digital addictions. This equates to roughly 5% of the 4,665 petitions we have handled since the beginning of the year and as one of the largest filers of divorce petitions in the UK, is a pretty good indicator. Has your relationship hit the rocks because of Fortnite? Email webnews@trinitymirror   The game is a survival shooter, which has been downloaded more than 100 million times and been endorsed by stars such as footballer Dele Alli and rapper Drake. It sees up to 100 players play against each other in a iety of game modes and is free to play. It is hugely popular with children and teenagers because it can be played on mobile phones but it appears the highly addictive game is not only affecting youngsters. Fortnite's most popular format is the BattleRoyale which sees 100 players fight each other on an island until one is left standing.  The game is available on mobiles and consoles including Xbox One and PlayStation 4, as well as PC and Mac. Earlier this week  reported how a disabled mother said she was left cash-strapped by her 10-year-old son spent who thousands on Fortnite. Single mum-of-two Cleo Duckett, 46, said she discovered her bank account had just &pound8 left in it on Friday night. Cleo, from Cefn Glas in Bridgend and on benefits as she suffers from polio and is on a wheelchair, said she has had to dig funds out of her son's savings pot in order to make until her next benefit payment on September 6.

title: incredible gesture three pupils who
story: NewsIncredible gesture by three pupils who saw a boy crying on the bus after his first day at secondary schoolThe 11-year-old had got on the wrong bus, and was getting further and further from his Liverpool home when the trio stepped inShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKate Mcmullin20:20, 7 SEP 2018Updated21:00, 7 SEP 2018NewsDylan Robson, a pupil at Holy Family Catholic High School in Liverpool, helped another student who got lost "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum says her faith in humanity has been restored after three schoolboys came to the aid of a crying and lost Year 7 pupil. The 11-year-old had got on the wrong bus, and was getting further and further from home when the kind-hearted trio stepped in. The boy, who did not have a phone or any money had no means of getting home to Netherton, Liverpool, the Liverpool Echo reports. However, after spotting him crying, Year 11 student Tom O'Brien gave the boy &pound10 for a taxi, while Year 7 students Harry Campbell and Dylan Robson made sure he got home safe. The act of kindness was shared on Facebook by a mum and has since gone viral with thousands commenting on the post to congratulate the boys. Collette, Harry's mum, said the whole situation 'restores faith in humanity'.  She said: It was my husband who saw Harry standing outside the house, talking to this boy we had never seen before. Harry had told Dylan to ring the taxi to pick him up from our house, to make sure he got home safe. Then he had walked him to ours and was stood outside waiting until the taxi came. God love him, this little fella was upset and had got on the wrong bus and with it being his first day wouldn't have known very many people either. I asked Harry had he seen the boy today and how he was and he said he was fine and had thanked him. I just think it is lovely. I'm very proud of him. It puts faith back in humanity and that little fella will know there are good people who will help him.  Tom told teachers he was just happy the boy had got home safe and was pleased that teenagers are getting some good publicity. Now his dad Kenny has spoken out about how proud he is of his thoughtful and caring son. The 55-year-old said: I am very proud of him. He is a very thoughtful lad and has a great personality. He didn't tell me what had happened until later in the night when he realised people were talking about it on Facebook. He just said he was on the bus asking the Year 7's how they had got on, on their first day and he noticed this kid sat on his own, looking anxious and upset and asked him was he okay. The boy said he had got on the wrong bus and was getting further and further away from home so Tom thought on his feet, told him to get off the bus and gave him &pound10 for a taxi. Dylan's mum Toni said she heard about what happened when her son got home from school. She said: He came home and said that there was a boy on the wrong bus and he was upset. He told me about Tom giving him the money and how he and Harry had rang a taxi. I asked him how he had known the number to ring and he said he had Googled it. I am very proud of him. I would hope that if it was my son in the same situation, someone would have helped him.

story: NewsLittle-known supermarket where you can get 60 per cent off big name brands - but there's a catchCompany Shop customers in Manchester can bag themselves incredible bargains - but only if they meet certain criteriaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRebecca Day10:32, 8 SEP 2018NewsThe Company Shop aims to reduce food waste"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email There's nothing like the feeling of bagging yourself a great bargain at the supermarket .   Everyone's guilty of scouring the shelves at Tesco or Asda, looking for usually expensive items at dirt cheap prices.  But Manchester's best kept secret could save you big, big bucks. The Company Shop, which is tucked away on an industrial estate in Middleton, sells surplus food at discounted prices to reduce waste and give back to the community. But there's a catch, because you need to be a member to go and are only allowed to bring one guest in at a time.   What is The Company Shop?   The Company Shop sells surplus food and household items from other stores. The food costs about 60 per cent less than its recommended retail price, according to the Manchester Evening News.  Surplus stock includes items that are misshapen, close to their sell-by date or have damaged or incorrect promotional packaging. The Company Shop sells items from places like ASDA, Morrisons, The Co-operative, M&ampS, Tesco, Nestl&eacute, Ocado, Tetley, Young’s and Muller.  Who can shop there?   The shop is strictly members only, although members can bring one guest with them per visit. To become a member, you must fit the following criteria:  Be over 18 years of age Work in the emergency services – including the fire brigade, police and those employed directly by the NHS, or Be a current or retired employee by one of their partners - ie a company that supplies food to the Company Shop. The Company Shop has a long list of suppliers across the food industry, and its website advises people wanting to apply to be members to check with their employers to see if they are signed up to the membership scheme.    If you meet the above criteria, you can apply via this form wwwpanyshop/company-shop/who-is-company-shop-for/membership-application-form .   Why do they sell surplus food?  The food industry throws away around 3.5m tonnes of food away every year. The Company Shop aims to reduce this waste, and so sells the surplus food on at low prices. If it didn’t do this, the food would end up in landfill.   Does the Company Shop have any plans to expand its membership criteria?  As stock is limited, the Company Shop believe it is important to follow strict rules on membership. There are currently five Company Shop stores in the UK, with a sixth due to open in September. When the store opening, Company Shop director Tom Rumboll told the Manchester Evening News: “We’ve had such a warm reception in Middleton.

story: NewsNew Asda supercentre store opens - with four surprising new featuresCustomers at Patchway Asda in Bristol will be able to make use of lots of new and exciting services at the newly refurbished storeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience EditorTristan Cork13:35, 8 SEP 2018Updated13:39, 8 SEP 2018NewsWork has begun on the refurb"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLong gone are the days of having to pop to lots of different shops to get all your weekly essentials, and supermarkets now offer customers pretty much everything they need under one roof. As well as food, clothing, household items and everything else it currently stocks, Asda is now offering three new features in one of its stores - and they're rather surprising additions.  The Bristol shop is being transformed into a Super Centre as part of a &pound8.2m refurbishment, reports Bristol Live .  The first new addition is a 'concept cafe', which is designed like a rainforest and will include table service and a 'premium menu'.  Another new addition will be a photo printing service. Max Spielmann already has bases in Tesco stores in the area, and will now also be offering its services to Asda customers. As well as tucking into a nice meal and getting their photos printed, customers will also be able to have a haircut at the new barbers shop at the site. In the clothing department at Patchway Asda customers will also be able to try out new digital screens which will model the items, and show how they can be adapted for different weather and trends. It's the first time the screens have appeared in any of the chain's stores, and it's sure to be a big hit with customers.  The store, which is located between The Mall and the M5 near Cribbs Causeway, will also become only the second Asda in the country to have a 'new innovative Cleveron click and collect tower parcel vending machine'. A store spokesperson said the tower, which acts as a giant parcel vending machine, is located inside the store so customers can pick up their online order in less than 60 seconds and will also take returns. title: ordinary peoples wages stagnate politicians
story: NewsopinionAs ordinary people's wages stagnate, politicians are more than ever in awe of the greedy bankersTheir recklessness may have ruined millions of lives but not one senior banker has been jailed in the UKShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrian Reade18:51, 7 SEP 2018NewsopinionGreedy bankers are still getting eye-watering bonuses post-crash "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt's funny how we all celebrate big anniversaries in different ways.  Take Boris Johnson , who’s decided in his 25th wedding anniversary year to let it be known his marriage is dead, so when he makes a play for the Tory leadership his leg-over longings won’t count against him.   Then there’s Tony Blair , who took time out from lobbying for a gas &shypipeline on behalf of his autocratic Azerbaijani paymasters, to give an important interview with the BBC.  As we hit the 10th anniversary of the banking crash, was he finally going to admit that his government’s lax &shyregulation and its attitude of being “intensely relaxed” about the rich getting richer, helped cause the worst depression since the 1920s? Maybe an apology, or an attack on The Big Swinging Dicks who caused it, then were allowed to speed past the rest of us in shiny red Lamborghinis while we sat in clapped-out Ladas in the slow lane? No. Just an attack on a Labour Party leadership that is proposing policies that would rein in the City-led greed that holds our country back. This past decade, while banks have grown bigger, richer and more untouchable on taxpayer subsidies, ordinary people have been punished with a brutal austerity programme which has seen their wages stagnate and personal debt rocket. Their recklessness may have ruined millions of lives but not one senior banker has been jailed in the UK or one judge-led inquiry into their countless acts of criminality set up.  Today our banking system has more capital behind it than it has done for a century yet the wider economy has suffered the lowest decade for growth since Victorian times. They’re still Masters of The Universe, enjoying eye-watering pay, bonuses and payoffs, and the subservient politicians who encouraged their reckless greed a decade ago are even more in awe of them. It’s as though the political class has deliberately refused to learn anything from that seismic crash. The mantra from on high is still that without these financial “wealth creators” our public services would start collapsing. Even though, like that dated economic model itself, they already have.

title: snaring snake how gut instinct
story: NewsSnaring the snake: How 'gut instinct' helped capture serial rapist who terrorised victim with 9ft pythonSick John Dickson - who raped one woman 1,000 times over five years, starved, almost suffocated and locked her in his house - was snared thanks to police perseverance and instinctShare&nbspByAnna Slater12:15, 8 SEP 2018Updated12:31, 8 SEP 2018NewsJohn Dickson and his 9ft snake"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA vile rapist who terrorised a victim with his huge pet snake - and beat, starved and tortured other women - was snared thanks to police instinct. Sick John Dickson had spent two decades subjecting ious women to horrific abuse. The labourer, who had raped, beaten and psychologically tortured women for two decades, was passive as handcuffs fixed his arms behind his back. Last week, Dickson appeared visibly shaken at the High Court in Glasgow as he was sentenced to 14 years in jail, with a further four-year restrictions order. It was an impressive result following an extensive investigation, triggered by a relatively minor report of Dickson throwing a mobile phone at a partner. The assault had happened last year on February 24, the Daily Record reports.  The victim's mother had reported it a week later and the task force investigation was launched on April 3, 2017. Detective Sergeant Iain Renfrew had spotted the complaint among the daily reports of all domestic incidents across Scotland, routinely sent to a task force. Experience led Iain to scan Dickson's previous record, where he saw a few complaints - not extreme, but they related to a number of partners over several years, usually at weekends, when Dickson's drunk. And there were reports from neighbours who had heard rows in Dickson's Motherwell flat, and sounds of crying. Iain said: Gut instinct told me it was the tip of the iceberg.  Victims will usually have experienced dozens of assaults before they eventually pick up the phone to police. There were multiple partners and indications of a pattern of behaviour over the years. I thought it was worth digging into Dickson further. The case was passed to Detective Constable John McFarlane to look at Dickson retrospectively and trace previous partners who could confirm if Iain's instincts were right that Dickson's potentially a serious abuser of women. This retrospective strategy has been so effective in establishing the essential element of corroboration that the blueprint has been mirrored by Police Scotland's rape task force. DC The Police Scotland domestic abuse task force  set up in 2009, signalled a neapproach in prioritising the crime across Scotland.  It is a collaborative offensive, involving specialist courts, greater consultation with the Crown and pulling in victim support agencies like ASSIST and Women's Aid to take care of women's emotional needs. Such abuse, once too often dismissed as just a domestic, now had an elite group of specialist officers tackling it with the intensity of a murder investigation. Detective Inspector David Cockburn oversees the DATF's West team and in 2018, his task force, together with those in the North and East areas of Police Scotland, have racked up sentences equating to more than a century of jail time for domestic abusers. He said: Proving these cases has been notoriously difficult in the past because the vast majority of domestic abuse happens behind closed doors with just the two people present, one word against another. It is difficult to get enough corroborative evidence and that's where we come in, as specialists digging that bit deeper to find what is needed for a successful prosecution. Going back to previous partners has to be handled sensitively and with skill. We are aware they will have tried to move on with their lives. We are conscious of taking them back, to a horrible experience and of re-traumatising them. That's why we also need to make sure they can access any emotional support they need.  The starting block is usually with the partner who is deeper in the past, who is likely to have broken off all contact with the abuser. When John introduced himself at the doors of Dickson's partners, there was an instant response. He said: When I said I was from the task force, they sensed I was there to talk about Dickson. Their reactions were visceral. One woman opened the door, initially bubbly and relaxed, but her face darkened at the mention of his name and there were tears. Another looked away and stared at the wall for a few seconds, unable to speak. In this job, I have never dealt with a victim who has truly moved on. They may think they have but they still experience flashbacks, triggers from TV or mayb e from something they have read.  Sometimes it takes the inquiry for them to see the psychological barriers that have existed far beyond the end of the relationship. The officers are careful not to lead or coerce victims and can't share if others have come forward, in case they feel pressurised to co-operate. Not all of Dickson's victims felt they could be involved but the four who did relayed horrifying stories of psychological and physical abuse by Dickson, over a period stretching from 2000 and 2017. One woman was raped more than 1000 times between 2000 and 2005, including in a train toilet. He battered her, spat on her, derided her with insults. He terrorised another by attacking her with his pet 9ft snake. The court heard Dickson'so fathered a child with another woman while dating her.  One was so scared of him she was found cowering in a storage cupboard near his flat. He tried to suffocate his last partner with a plastic bag and attempted to strangle her. The psychological control he had over his victims was absolute and he was meticulous in its execution. Dickson timed partners when they went to the shops and he forensically examined receipts. He told some what to wear, how to have their hair. He liked pigtails and, in his words, easy access clothing. Despite having been independent career women, he forbade them from having jobs, leaving them financially at his mercy. He locked them in the house or hid the keys if he was there. If they visited family, he would call the land line to check they were there. He harangued one woman, telling her she was overweight, despite her tiny frame, and he hid food from her until she was malnourished. During an extensive interview following his ARREST, Dickson didn't ask for a lawyer but stared emotionlessly at the desk in front of him, responding no comment as a stream of allegations were put to him. If the silent tactic had worked in the past, it wouldn't this time. David said: He was used to dealing with response officers over isolated incidents. He was probably blase, thinking it was going to be a quick interview and out the door but he would soon see this was a whole different ball game. Before Dickson's ARRESTed, the DATF had meticulously constructed a compelling case, a fat file of evidence, which would run to 50,000 words by the time the case hit court. The procurator fiscal had been regularly briefed and was able to present 59 charges to the court. For the officers, there is an inevitable sense of duty towards the victims who have entrusted them with intimate, harrowing experiences. For some victims, it is a healing process.

title: storm florence could batter uk
story: NewsStorm Florence could batter UK with 65mph gales if path steers away from USMet Office forecasters say Britain is braced for 'gales and heavy rain' as the course of Storm Florence may alterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly22:13, 7 SEP 2018NewsThese forecast images suggest Storm Florence may in fact be heading towards Europe "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailViolent remnants of Storm Florence may lash 65mph gales and downpours across the UK, these startling computer model images show. The tropical blast is currently swirling across the Atlantic towards the US and it's feared it may be upgraded to a hurricane by the time it reaches the country.  But new digital graphics created by meteorologists measuring the course of Storm Florence show it may veer away from the US and into Europe's - and the UK's - path by the middle of the month.   Forecasters say it's effects won't be as devastating but will batter the country with 65mph gusts and heavy rain.  Lee Robertson, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service , assessed the image of the new jet-stream and called it still a possibility.   And Dr Claire Kennedy-Edwards, a Weather Channel meteorologist, said: Others [forecast models] show the storm re-curving around the subtropical ridge as the remnants of Florence get entrained into the jet stream.  Latest model runs show a iety of downstream effects for western Europe. However some forecast models are favouring a more westward track for Tropical Storm Florence, which could impact north-eastern areas of the US.   The Met Office in the UK does fear some extremely unsettled weather from around September 15 but cannot confirm if this as a result of Storm Florence.  It says: Occasional spells of more unsettled weather are likely, these mainly in the northwest where there is a risk of gales and heavy rain at times, and with the rain perhaps occasionally spreading across other areas.

title: teenage girl sent home school
story: NewsTeenage girl sent home from school because trousers mum bought from Asda were 'too tight'Scarlett O'Donoghue, 14, was one of around 40 pupils given their marching orders or put into isolation at Forge Valley School in SheffieldShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly20:29, 7 SEP 2018Updated21:53, 7 SEP 2018NewsScarlett O'Donoghue, 14, in the skirt deemed 'too tight' by her Sheffield school "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teenage girl was sent home on the second day of the new school term after teachers insisted her trousers from Asda were too tight, her mum claims.   Some 40 pupils from Forge Valley School in Malin Bridge, Sheffield, were given their marching orders or put into isolation on Thursday for breaking the zero tolerance uniform rules.  Scarlett O'Donoghue, 14, was pulled to one side by a teacher and told to change her trousers - for which mum Claire paid &pound27 for three pairs from the Asda school range - or go home.  And staff rang her furious mum Claire, 42, to tell her Scarlett was not allowed in class. She said: Scarlett was so excited about starting her GCSEs - I was livid. We've not got a lot of money and Scarlett knows we've not got &pound50 to spend on an outfit she can't wear. What I cannot get over is what right does one teacher have to say my child's trousers are too tight?  Claire forking out &pound51 on three pairs of trousers and three skirts but teachers said the clothing was unacceptably tight. The mum-to-two, who runs a glazing firm with husband Michael, 51, added: Scarlett thinks she's too fat like a lot of teenage girls - for someone in authority to 'say your clothes are too tight' is disgusting. A lot of girls also have issues about their weight and their body image. So if you have an adult telling you the skirt is too tight it's going to hugely harm your self-esteem. What is that saying to teenage girls about their self-confidence when they are already worried about their weight. They're sexualising young girls who should be allowed to wear whatever they want to wear.  Scarlett has been very upset and angry about the whole thing. We spent over &pound50 on new school uniforms and the school are not going to give me that back. It was the second time Scarlett had been pulled up over uniform after she arrived in school the previous day wearing a skirt which staff also said was unacceptably tight. An online petition has been signed by more than 500 parents, angry with the uniform policy. But Dale Barrowclough, headteacher at the school, said: We have the uniform policy because it promotes a professional ethos in the school and it allows pupils who can't afford branded clothes to avoid bullying. This is something that was raised by parents and which is why they wanted the uniform policy and it would be unfair to change it now. I'm not prepared to relax our high standards. It's why Forge Valley is oversubscribed and we could not say that when the school opened. Parents are always given adequate warning about next year's uniform in my end of summer term letter which says that full uniform must be worn for the start of September. Mr Barrowclough said a small number of pupils were sent home from school on Wednesday but said he could empathise with parents over buying uniforms.

title: teenage girl who masterminded shocking
story: NewsTeenager who masterminded shocking 2am knife attack on her ex-boyfriend and new partner is jailedAnna Dickinson, 18, was sentenced to 32 months in a young offenders institution over the attack on ex-boyfriend Tyrone Baines, also 18, and his new loverShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy WalkerElaine McCahill13:58, 7 SEP 2018Updated17:53, 7 SEP 2018NewsAnna Dickinson masterminded a shocking 2am knife attack on her ex-boyfriend and his new lover  Ltd"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager who masterminded a shocking 2am knife attack on her ex-boyfriend and his new lover after discovering they were having a romance was jailed today. Jealous college student Anna Dickinson, 18, recruited two friends to help her launch a savage assault on Tyrone Baines, also 18, in the dead of night after she learnt he was dating another girl. After making threats to ‘'bang’' and ‘'stab’' his new girlfriend, Dickinson and her accomplices burst into 18-year old Mr Baines' home in Lancaster whilst the couple were in bed together. The three swarmed around Mr Baines and left him with three stab wounds to the back and a bite mark. Dickinson and her best friend Kathryn Stanley, 18, then burst into his bedroom where the unnamed girl, 17, was lying in bed naked. Stanley jumped on top of his girlfriend, punched her to the head and held her arms to stop her defending herself as Dickinson stabbed at her and tried to cut her hair off as a way of ''degrading'' her.  The assault only ended when Stanley said: “I didn’t think you were going to stab her.''  Baines and his girlfriend later received stitches for the several serious lacerations and stab wounds but made a miraculous recovery.  In a statement the girl said she feared she would be killed and added: “Since the incident I have struggled with my anxiety and stress due to what happened when I was stabbed by Anna. “I am so scared of them and I will go out of my way to never be see them again. I struggle day to day now to leave the house without somebody. What they did to me will stay with me for the rest of my life and I will always have the scars on my back. “I have started counselling and I am trying to deal with how to trust people again in my life. I am scared and fearful of them. She was contacting my friends and calling me a liar and trying to intimidate me.” At Preston Crown Court Dickinson, Stanley and Jordan Gardner, 18, all of Lancaster admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent and unlawful wounding. Dickinson and Stanley were locked up for 32 months in a young offenders institution and Gardner a close friend of Tyrone was detained for 21 months.  As sentences were passed fighting broke out between loved ones of the families.  The incident took place on February 19 after Tyrone split up with Dickinson following a four month fling and began dating the other girl. Prosecutor Raymond Smith said: “Dickinson and the girl had been friends and known each other for some years.  But the friendship between the two of them deteriorated to the point Dickinson sent messages via social media threatening to “bang” and “stab” her. That day Dickinson had sent messages to Tyrone asking if his girlfriend was at home. ''Some time later Tyrone and his partner went to bed and fell asleep.  Two hours later, Tyrone was woken up by Gardner shouting to be let in. Tyrone got out of bed partially dressed and went downstairs and heard Gardner trying to get in through the living room window. “Tyrone opened the door and Gardner came into the house running upstairs, whilst Dickinson and Stanley also came into the house and came running upstairs.  Dickinson was carrying a knife and Tyrone recognised it as being from the kitchen. In light of the previous threats Tyrone was scared for his girlfriend and he tried to hold the bedroom door shut.  “But Dickinson was stabbing at him trying to get around him. Tyrone was trying to reason with the two women. Tyrone was being stabbed many times by Dickinson. Eventually he failed to stop them gaining entry to the bedroom and witnessed the attack on his partner. “By this stage Gardner was leaving and had left the house. Tyrone had sustained stab wounds to the neck and back and had cuts to the back and bruises to his neck where Dickinson had tried to bite him when she was trying to get past him. “The female victim could see that Tyrone was struggling with the two women and she could see a knife in Dickinson's hand.  Stanley ran into the room and jumped on top of her and punched her to the head and body. She held her wrists making it difficult for her to defend herself. “She remembers the blade of the knife being held to her throat and being stabbed on her arm by Dickinson. She then remembers Stanley shouting: “I didn’t think you were going to stab her.” Tyrone had gone to get the two women out of the bedroom when the female noticed she was bleeding from many wounds.  In her statement she said she was frightened and thought she was going to be killed.  The girl suffered stab wounds to her arms neck and face plus wounds to her left upper back and chest.  Tyrone had wounds to his back and chest.  After the attack Dickinson called her mother requesting a lift and made a telephone call at 4am to tell a friend what she had done. Mr Smith added: “Dickinson played a leading role in the group attack. It is aggravated by the location and time of the offence, this was in the victim’s bedroom when she was naked and asleep.'' Dickinson's lawyer Amanda Hamilton said: “She is accepting of what happened and has deep regrets and hurt for the two people who suffered significant wounds.  She was in a relationship with Tyrone, he was the man she loved and there was a desperate nature of the relationship, it was a difficult one. She wishes she didn’t attend Tyrone’s house in that night. “She accepts she went to the house and took a weapon with her but she didn’t make threats to use the weapon. She wants to face up to and understand what happened that night. She wants the victims to know how truly sorry she is.   “She has done a lot of volunteer work with animals, she enjoys working with cats and dogs . She has an extremely supportive family.  She doesn’t recall sending these messages and they have disappeared from social media, but as the prosecution witnesses are saying they received them, she accepts that. Since her arrest she has found a group of friends who support her.”  Robert Elias for Stanley, said: “She did not have a quarrel, she had not been scorned but she was holding Dickinson's hand. She had no knowledge of her friend picking up the knife. This wasn’t premeditated, she didn’t knew it was going to happen. “Once the momentum began she took part. She climbed by that young lady, struck her, then unknowing there was a knife she offered the responsibility and prospect of matters getting worse. She was horrified, she was shouting about the need for it to happen.  “Since the incident she has moved counties. She presents to be quite an intelligent young woman and is frustrated with herself for having got in this situation, she doesn’t blame Miss Dickinson, she thinks she should have seen through the anger before there was this confrontation. “ She was there for other reasons, she wanted to show loyalty and to help her friend. She is wanting to make a go of things.” Sentencing Judge Heather Lloyd said: “Tyrone Baines and the female victim began to get close and it was clear you did not like the fact they were together. It is clear from the messages you were threatening to stab his girlfriend and on that night that is precisely what you did.

title: time capsule home abandoned owner
story: NewsOrdinary-looking three-bedroom house hides some incredible 'time capsule' secrets insideThe modest three-bedroom semi - built in 1937 - looks like the rest of the suburban street from the outside but is a time capsule insideShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNathan Sandhu17:03, 7 SEP 2018Updated09:43, 8 SEP 2018NewsAaron Whiteside steps back into the 1930s at this property "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEverytime Aaron Whiteside goes through his front door he steps back into the 1930s - after transforming his home into one for the pre-war era. Aaron, 36, has dreamt of living in a 1930s' home complete with authentic gadgets and furniture from the era ever since he was a five-year-old boy. He is the proud owner of a modest three-bedroom semi - built in 1937 - looks like the rest of the suburban street from the outside but is a time capsule inside. Everything inside is from a bygone era, including the rare wallpaper, coal fires and electric cooker which was one of the first of its kind. Aaron recalls browsing junk shops aged five, picking up an old radiogram, hoover, mincers and gas lamps during trips with his grandmother's sister. Since then, he has slowly become enamoured with the decade's style and way of life. He bought his current home in Blackpool, Lancs., for &pound87,000 in 2007 after it had stood empty for nearly a decade.  The enthusiast has worked tirelessly to transform the house - installing German wallpaper which was buried in a time capsule in the 1930s and cost Aaron &pound100 a roll. He sleeps in a vintage bed, has a GEC cooker, doesn't own a television or fridge and still uses a laundry mangle. Not content with just looking like it's in the 1930s, the house also runs like a pre-war one would have, heated by four coal fires and without double glazing windows. He said: From the age of five I always liked the music, a lot of people think I've been here before. My grandmother's sister would take me round junk shops and I collected a lot of gramophones.  The first ever item I bought was an old radiogram from the 1950s and an old hoover, as well old mincers and gas lamps. It's all bits like that as to how it all started and it's got a bit out of hand since. I've tried to make sure all the items in the house are originals, rather than being replicas. My pride of joy is an HMV state of the art gramophone from 1937. It came from an old house down south where bits and pieces were being sold off, and a friend of a friend told me about it. Anyone that comes to the house absolutely love it, I'm not saying they would want to live in it but I've not really had any bad feedback. Aaron, who has no children, loves 1930s vocalists including Judy Garland, Jessie Matthews and Billie Holiday and even watches silent films.  When at home, he wears vintage clothes, sports a slick back undercut hairstyle and bearded finish and eats a 1930s diet - including cooking foods in beef dripping. The house was built in 1937 so this house always had a toilet, he added. It runs on coal so I have to lit the fire in the backroom for hot water. If I buy a rib of beef and have friends for tea I will cook it the old fashioned way, I don't use oil.  The washing machine I've got is a Hotpoint electric one with a mangle. The hoover is a 1934 electric hoover senior which I have been using since I was kid. The wall masks I collected are hard to come by, they are by an artist called John Douglas. I have the King up on the wall and there are thirties art decor original pictures. There is the Victorian organ in there as well as a great big Edwardian sideboard. The kitchen has got the original tiles and sink and cupboards. It's pretty bog standard to how it was when it was built. The hallway is pretty much as it was apart from it's got new wallpaper, it's an old reprint. The items I have sort of go up to the 1940s. Even at the end of the war, you were still living in the thirties because there was no production.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Early winter freeze to grip Britain with sub-zero temperatures and frosty windsTemperatures will remain above average through September, but sub-zero temperatures could sweep across the country in OctoberShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitchingCharlotte Smith11:28, 8 SEP 2018Updated11:42, 8 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/watch-latest-weather-forecast-uk-13210901,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An early winter freeze bringing uncomfortable cold and frosty winds could grip Britain within weeks, forecasters have warned.  Sub-zero temperatures could sweep across the country in late October and leave shivering Britons longing for this summer's heatwave. The weather will be a mixed bag in the coming days and weeks - with heavy rain and strong winds in some places and warm sunshine in others - before temperatures eventually plunge. This weekend will be wet and windy across much of the UK with a washout expected in parts of Wales.  As much as 40-50mm of rain could fall in some places in Wales by Sunday night. The heaviest rain on Saturday will be over north-west Wales and north-west England, with outbreaks of rain in central parts of the UK. Much of Scotland will be dry with some sunny spells. Rain will continue to fall across central regions and spread north into Northern Ireland and southern Scotland on Saturday night, with chilly temperatures in north-west Scotland.    On Sunday, the rain will clear to sunshine and showers across Scotland and Northern Ireland. England and Wales will be cloudy with patchy rain moving to the south-east, but it will feel warm in any sunshine across the south. Forecasters say a north-south divide is poised to take hold of Britain early next week. It will be cool and wet in the northern half of the country, while the south will see the return of an Indian Summer. Daytime temperatures are forecast to potentially drop to the low teens in parts of northern England and Scotland, while highs will be around the mid teens to low 20s elsewhere, with the best of the warmth in the south-east.  Sarah Sammy, a forecaster with The Weather Channel, said after an unsettled weekend conditions will improve across the south, but stay very mixed in the north.   She said: Rain will affect much of the north on Monday, particularly in the northwest. This will gradually extend across Ireland to affect northwest England, Wales and the Midlands during the day. The far south and southeast should be drier but cloudy, likewise for the northeast and eastern Scotland in the later afternoon. Maximum temperatures will range from 14 to 19C in the north and 15 to 21C in the south. By Tuesday, the mercury should rise up to 3-5C above average for the time of year across the south, with highs of 24C likely in the capital. It'll be a largely cloudy day for all. But umbrellas will be needed in northern and western regions as low pressure is set to bring persistent, and at times heavy, outbreaks of above average rainfall. Ms Sammy added: Tuesday should see further rain across Ireland, Scotland, Wales and Northern England. The Midlands and southern England should remain mostly dry with sunny spells developing - it'll feel very warm in these areas too.

story: NewsGirl 'had slept with 100 men by 16 and had baby at 15 after being passed around by abusers'Her harrowing video interview was played at the trial of eight Asian men accused of sexual abuse of five girlsShare&nbspByBen McVay12:39, 8 SEP 2018Updated12:55, 8 SEP 2018NewsTanweer Ali, 36, arrives at Sheffield Crown Court after being accused of indecently assaulting the girl "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young girl was passed around and had sex with 100 men by the time she was 16, a child abuse trial was told. The girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons, claims the abuse she suffered between 1998 and 2001 began when she was just 13 years old, jurors heard. Her video interview was played at the trial of eight men accused of sexual abuse of five girls over a five-year period from 1998 to 2003. They were arrested and charged as part of Operation Stovewood - a police investigation into sexual abuse launched after the Rotherham grooming scandal. Sheffield Crown Court, South Yorkshire, heard how her number would be passed around between the men - with others then demanding to meet her. She said: I can honestly say that by the age of 16 I had slept with 100 Asian men - some I didn't see again.  The ones who come and use you for one time are the ones who are hard to remember. As soon as you get to know them your number gets passed around. Asian lads demanding to meet you - then you meet a new group and it went on like that. I didn't know at the time I was being passed around when I was 13 but I know now I'm older. Tanweer Ali, 37, and Mohammed Imran Ali Akhtar, 37, are both accused of indecently assaulting the girl between 1998 and 2001 when she was under the age of 16. Ali and Akhtar would have been aged between 17 and 20 during the alleged period of offending. The victim described how she initially disliked Ali Akhtar, of Rotherham.  However she eventually 'fell' for the delivery driver when he made her feel special by visiting her every day after he finished his shift in the early hours of the morning. She fell pregnant with his son at the age of 14 and gave birth to him when she was 15. The victim claimed sexual activity with Ali Akhtar continued throughout pregnancy. She told how and after their son was born, she 'tricked' him into meeting him when he visited her hoping for sex. She said: I never saw him again after that. The victim told how her sister was also allegedly abused by Ali Akhtar and said the abuse they suffered made it feel as though their childhoods were snatched away.  She said: Before, we would just enjoy going on holiday with our granddad but we had advantage taken of us - we were children one minute and adults the next. We were snatched away. Ali, also of Rotherham, and Ali Akhtar are on trial with six other men, all accused of committing historic sex offences in Rotherham against five alleged victims. They face a total of 28 counts of sexual abuse of five girls over a five-year period from 1998 to 2003. Akhtar, of Rotherham, faces four counts of indecent assault, one of supplying a controlled drug, one of rape, one of procuring a girl under 21 for unlawful sexual intercourse with another, one of aiding and abetting a rape and one of sexual assault.

title: abby hernandez reveals tactics used
story: NewsAbby Hernandez reveals 'tactics' she used to stay alive during nine month kidnap ordeal as she was torturedAbby Hernandez was abducted after leaving school on October 9, 2013, sparking a desperate search that ended when she walked into her family's home nine months laterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitchingAmber Hicks22:56, 7 SEP 2018Updated22:58, 7 SEP 2018NewsAbby Hernandez was 14 when she was abducted"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKidnap victim Abby Hernandez has revealed how she stayed alive during the nine month ordeal in which she was sexually assaulted and tortured. The teen, who was abducted on her way home from school, said her survival instincts kicked in and she realised she had to work with the man holding her captive.  I said [to him], ‘I don’t judge you for this. If you let me go, I won’t tell anybody about this,’” Abby recalled during an interview with ABC News .  However her initial attempts to negotiate with her sick abductor proved unsuccessful and for nine months he forced her to wear a dog shock collar and call him Master.  Twisted Nate Kibby inflicted abuse on her daily, but she used the 'power of prayer' to keep her hope alive. She added: “I remember I never said ‘amen’ in my mind. I never wanted to end my prayers because I didn't want God to leave me. “I just really wanted to live.” One of the other tactics Ms Hernandez used was to think strategically and establish a bond with her captor. She said: “I told him, ‘Look, you don't seem like a bad person. Like, everybody makes mistakes… If you let me go, I won't tell anybody about this.’”  Ms Hernandez, then 14, was hidden away in a storage container where she was drugged, repeatedly raped and psychologically tortured before finally being released. She was abducted after leaving school on October 9, 2013, sparking a desperate search that ended when she walked into her family's home nine months later. For the first time, Ms Hernandez, 19, has described her ordeal in detail and told how she is coping years on from the abduction in the US town of Conway, New Hampshire.  In an exclusive interview, she told the ABC News programme 20/20 that Kibby put a dog shock collar on her to stop her from screaming and alerting people nearby.   He also told her to call him Master and claimed that he had rigged the storage container on his property in Gorham - about 30 miles from where he abducted the girl - to erupt in flames if she tried to escape or if someone tried to save her. Ms Hernandez said: “He said, ‘You know, I’m thinking of finding something a little more humane for you to keep you quiet. “He said, ‘I’m thinking of a shock collar’, you know, like dogs wear. “I remember he put it on me and he told me, ‘OK, try and scream’. I just slowly started raising my voice and then it shocked me. “He was like, ‘OK, now you know what it feels like’.”  She added: “He told me call me ‘Master’.” Kibby, now 37, claimed he had rigged the storage container's door with wires and screws, telling Ms Hernandez that she would die if someone tried to rescue her. She told ABC News correspondent Deborah Roberts: “He told me that he tripped the door so that if for any reason it was busted open it would catch on fire. “If somebody kicked open the door I would go up in flames, basically.” She thought Kibby was watching her remotely because a surveillance camera was always blinking.  Ms Hernandez said she used psychological strategies to stay alive, including bonding with Kibby. She didn't know his name until she found it inside a cookbook he had given her while she was being held. Kibby had kidnapped her after offering her a ride home, and pulled out a gun and threatened to shoot her when she tried to get out of his car. She didn't know him but accepted the ride because her feet were sore and blistered.
